awd_titl_txt: The Inquiry-Based Learning Regional Communities Project
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this Exploration and Design project aims to serve the national interest by developing regional communities to support inquiry-based learning (IBL) in mathematics.  It also aims to recruit and help new faculty from diverse institutions implement IBL in undergraduate mathematics courses. The project will bring together faculty representatives from four regional IBL communities: the Maryland-DC-Virginia IBL Consortium, Michigan IBL Consortium, Midwest Regional IBL Community, and the New England IBL in Mathematics Consortium.  These faculty representatives will work together to investigate the potential for regional communities of IBL practitioners to support faculty in adopting, sustaining, and promoting the use of IBL in undergraduate mathematics education. This IBL Communities model will provide the ongoing support that instructors need to successfully adopt and sustain IBL strategies in the classroom. Furthermore, regional IBL communities have the potential to broadly impact mathematics education by creating synergy among diverse groups of IBL practitioners who will in turn garner support for IBL among other faculty, administrators, policy makers, and funders across each region. 

The overarching goal of the project is to provide targeted support to nurture the growth of the four regional IBL communities represented on the project team and to investigate the impact of these communities in each region.  The expectation is that the project's investigations will elucidate which community-building strategies are most effective in supporting faculty to adopt, sustain, and promote the use of IBL in undergraduate mathematics education. In support of this goal, the project team will collaborate with leaders in each of the four regions to pursue the following objectives: 1) establish and coordinate a Network of IBL Communities; 2) plan and implement regional IBL Communities workshops; 3) facilitate the planning and implementation of peer-collaboration activities in the regional IBL communities; 4) broaden participation in the regional IBL communities among faculty from groups that are underrepresented in STEM as well as among faculty from institution types that are underrepresented in the national IBL community; and 5) investigate the ability of regional IBL communities to provide faculty with the professional support they need to adopt, sustain, and promote IBL. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Institutional and Community Transformation track, the program supports efforts to transform and improve STEM education across institutions of higher education and disciplinary communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Broader Impacts: 

This project created the COMmunities for Mathematics Inquiry in Teaching (COMMIT) Network, of 14 regional “COMMIT communities” of college and university mathematics instructors interested in practicing and sharing teaching techniques involving student inquiry. The COMMIT Network has over 1000 faculty participants spread across 14 regional communities, with 57% of the U.S. population residing in a COMMIT region. These communities work at the grassroots level to provide workshops that meet the particular needs of their local members, without the expense of a plane ticket to a national conference. This project has generated workshop materials for the member communities and trained facilitators to offer these workshops. You can expect to find workshops in most of these communities multiple times per year.

By supporting the growth and sustainability of these communities—and broadening participation in them—this project has promoted the use of evidence-based teaching strategies in undergraduate mathematics classrooms across the country. COMMIT communities are helping to transform the teaching of college-level mathematics by ensuring that inquiry strategies are used to prepare more students for success, thereby contributing to the development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce, as called for by the NSF. This project has created a foundation for collaborations with additional stakeholders (e.g., university administrators, officers of professional organizations, PreK-12 educators) who seek to implement policies and programs supporting the widespread use of teaching with inquiry. Finally, just as the COMMIT community model is already being replicated within departments, the COMMIT Network model is suitable to be replicated in other STEM disciplines; this impacts reform across undergraduate STEM education.

Intellectual Merit:

The overarching research objective was to investigate whether the regional COMMITs provide faculty with the professional support they need to adopt, sustain, and promote teaching with inquiry. In its first 3 years (the original project timeline), the project included 14 meetings for the regional COMMIT leaders and over 200 hours of regional workshops and other events to support deep and active participation in the communities. The intellectual merit included examining community aspects of social learning in the COMMITs and using a framework for assessing value creation in communities. (For more on this framework, see Wenger, E., Trayner, B., & de Laat, M. (2011). Promoting and assessing value creation in communities and networks: A conceptual framework. Open University of the Netherlands.) COMMIT members reported, for example, developing trusting relationships in which they were comfortable sharing their successes and challenges in teaching. The project team generated six peer-reviewed articles, one book chapter (in press, as of this report), one blog interview, 17 peer-reviewed presentations, a COMMIT Network website that includes workshop facilitation and community-building materials, and a nonprofit organization.
